pullRequest.body:
Create the module `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.IsConnected`.

The main theorem states that the colimit of singletons is a singleton if and only if the index category is connected.

This theorem will be necessary for the Freyd-Mitchell embedding theorem.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: I think we should strengthen this even more, namely we should also show that the colimit of the constant functor always exists if `C` is connected. See [my branch](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/master...fme-100-markus)

In a review to #10420 I suggested improving the API for zigzag (in particular removing the `reducible` attribute to prevent leakage of the internals of the API), if possible try to coordinate with @dagurtomas in order to make sure API is consistent, see https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10420/commits/eb9ffb4710e2fe2146a49dc84665c3307790607a

In #10420 I add your `zag_of_hom` under the name `Zag.of_hom` and more stuff, I can open a separate PR with only the `Zigzag` API that can hopefully be merged quickly and we'll make both this PR and #10420 depend on it.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

`zag_of_hom` and `zigzag_of_hom` can go in `CategoryTheory/IsConnected.lean`, everything else I would put in a new file `Limits/IsConnected.lean`.

If you haven't done so yet, I recommend reading through these pages:

- https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/doc.html
- https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html
- https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html

```suggestion Nonempty (colimit F) → Nonempty C := fun ⟨q⟩ => ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (h : (colimitCocone F).ι.app c fc = (colimitCocone F).ι.app d fd) : Zigzag c d := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (h : colimit.ι F c fc = colimit.ι F d fd) : Zigzag c d := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion IsConnected C ↔ Nonempty (colimit (unitValuedFunctor C) ≅ PUnit) := by ```

How about
```suggestion
instance instSubsingletonColimitPUnit [IsPreconnected C] :
    Subsingleton (colimit (unitValuedFunctor C)) where
  allEq a b := by
    obtain ⟨c, ⟨⟩, rfl⟩ := jointly_surjective' a
    obtain ⟨d, ⟨⟩, rfl⟩ := jointly_surjective' b
    apply constant_of_preserves_morphisms (colimit.ι (unitValuedFunctor C) · PUnit.unit)
    exact fun c d f => colimit_sound f rfl

noncomputable def colimitConstPUnitIsoPUnit [IsConnected C] :
    colimit (unitValuedFunctor C) ≅ PUnit where
  hom := fun _ => PUnit.unit
  inv := fun _ => colimit.ι (unitValuedFunctor C) Classical.ofNonempty PUnit.unit
```
for that part.

Some notable Lean 4 syntax tricks:

- `\cdot` for implicit lambda expressions
- `obtain` destructures `⟨⟩` to `PUnit.unit` and lemmas introduced using `rfl` are automatically substituted.
Thanks especially for the neat `\cdot` trick!

Not really shorter, but in my opinion more conceputal:
```suggestion
  Nonempty.map (Sigma.fst ∘ Quot.out ∘ (colimitEquivQuot F).toFun)
```

I find the following approach based on induction and `colimit_eq` easier:
```suggestion
theorem zigzag_of_eqvGen_quot_rel (F : C ⥤ TypeMax.{u, v}) (c d : Σ j, F.obj j)
    (h : EqvGen (Quot.Rel F) c d) : Zigzag c.1 d.1 := by
  induction h with
  | rel _ _ h => exact zigzag_of_hom _ (Exists.choose h)
  | refl _ => rfl
  | symm _ _ _ ih => exact zigzag_symmetric ih
  | trans _ _ _ _ _ ih₁ ih₂ => exact ih₁.trans ih₂
  
theorem connected_iff_colimit_const_punit_iso_pUnit :
    IsConnected C ↔ Nonempty (colimit (unitValuedFunctor C) ≅ PUnit) := by
  refine ⟨fun _ => ⟨colimitConstPUnitIsoPUnit C⟩, fun ⟨h⟩ => ?_⟩
  have : Nonempty C := nonempty_of_nonempty_colimit _ (Nonempty.map h.inv inferInstance)
  refine zigzag_isConnected (fun c d => ?_)
  refine zigzag_of_eqvGen_quot_rel _ (unitValuedFunctor C) ⟨c, PUnit.unit⟩ ⟨d, PUnit.unit⟩ ?_
  exact colimit_eq <| h.toEquiv.injective rfl
```
This lemma is unused

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
```
This should go in `CategoryTheory/Limits/Types.lean`, I think

Personally, I find the readability tradeoff of embedding LaTex into docstrings not very favourable because while it looks good in the Mathlib docs, it looks less good when viewing the file in VS Code. Also, I would avoid mentioning the term "Set" here as this means something else in Mathlib.

I think it would be possible to milk this more to obtain the following two statements:

- For any universe `w`: if the constant functor with value `PUnit.{w + 1}` has a colimit and this colimit is isomorphic to `PUnit.{w + 1}`, then the category is connected.
- If the category is connected, then for any universe `w` the constant functor with value `PUnit.{w + 1}` has a colimit and this colimit is isomorphic to `PUnit.{w + 1}`.

I think that would make it possible to generalize the universes in your other PR.

I don't know, do you know a good way to do this elegantly? For example, `jointly_surjective'` assume thats `domain F : TypeMax`. Is there a reason why all these lemmas are proved in this situation and not for arbitrary types? Right now, the best I can come up is trying to generalize `jointly_surjective'` and its dependencies -- quite invasive.

Update: `colimit_sound` also assumes `TypeMax`. Instead of `jointly_surjective` I can use `jointly_surjective_of_isColimit` although it's slightly uglier.
I was able to generalize colimit_sound, too, so if I just use my generalization, it works.

```suggestion
    obtain ⟨c, ⟨⟩, rfl⟩ := jointly_surjective' a
    obtain ⟨d, ⟨⟩, rfl⟩ := jointly_surjective' b
```
I think this is a duplicate of `colimit_sound`?
Interesting... You're right. Now idea how that happened. :laughing:

The second one doesn't do anything if you're in the same namespace already, and the first one appears to be unused.

```suggestion
```
I think I would name this `constPUnitFunctor`

Assuming you accept my other name change suggestion:

```suggestion
theorem isConnected_iff_colimit_constPUnitFunctor_iso_pUnit
```

I think it would be nice to state also `IsConnected C ↔ Nonempty (IsColimit (pUnitCocone.{w} C))`.
Otherwise, it looks good to me.
I finally managed to implement that one. While I tried getting rid of the `have` instance, I found no good way, so I kept it.
Here, you should update the name of lemma.
Thanks, I've updated the names in the docstring and also incorporated other new lemmas.
The name of `unitValuedFunctor` also changed.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CategoryTheory.Limits.IsConnected): colimit of singletons is singleton iff index category is connected
